actions-list.actionItem: At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 773, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. D'Esposito demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 773.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 773 — "Providing for the expulsion of Representative George Santos from the House of Representatives."

actions-list.header: QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE
actions-list.actionItem: Mr. D'Esposito rose to a question of the privileges of the House and offered the resolution. The Chair directed the Clerk to report the resolution. Upon examination of the resolution, the Chair determined that the resolution did constitute a question of the privileges of the House.
Pursuant to clause 1(c) of rule XIX, the Chair announced further proceedings on H.R. 4364 would be postponed.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 4364.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 4394 and H.R. 4364. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 4394 and H.R. 4364. Resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 4394, under a structured rule with one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 4364 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit. The resolution lays H. Res. 699 on the table.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 756. H.R. 4364 — "Making appropriations for the Legislative Branch for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Acting Clerk notified the House that he had received the following message from the Secretary of the Senate on October 30, 2023 at 3:20 p.m.: That the Senate passed S. 1170.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency with respect to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction declared in Executive Order 12938 is to continue in effect beyond November 14, 2023.
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-76).

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Res. 798.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Owens moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended. H. Res. 798 — "Condemning the support of Hamas, Hezbollah, and other terrorist organizations at institutions of higher education, which may lead to the creation of a hostile environment for Jewish students, faculty, and staff."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3266.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lawler moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 3266 — "To require the Secretary of State to submit annual reports reviewing the curriculum used by the Palestinian Authority, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Res. 599.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Lawler moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution. H. Res. 599 — "Urging the European Union to designate Hizballah in its entirety as a terrorist organization."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3774.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lawler moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3774 — "To impose additional sanctions with respect to the importation or facilitation of the importation of petroleum products from Iran, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 340.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. McCaul moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 340 — "To impose sanctions with respect to foreign support for terrorist organizations, including Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Res. 559.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. McCaul moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution. H. Res. 559 — "Declaring it is the policy of the United States that a nuclear Islamic Republic of Iran is not acceptable."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Ms. Houlahan to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 1.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2.00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
